required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Effects of Oxycodone and Sufentanil on Cardiovascular Stress Induced by Tracheal Intubation in the Patients With Coronary Heart Disease Undergoing Major Noncardiac Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Effects of Oxycodone and Sufentanil on Cardiovascular Stress Induced by Tracheal Intubation in the Patients With Coronary Heart Disease Undergoing Major Noncardiac Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: To evaluate the effect of oxycodone and sufentanil in preventing cardiovascular responses to tracheal intubation in the patients with coronary heart disease (CHD).

detailed_description.textblock: Laryngoscopy and tracheal intubation can provoke an increase of blood pressure (BP) and/or HR [1.2]. This hemodynamic stress may lead to an imbalance between myocardial oxygen consumption and supply and therefore induce myocardial ischemia, which may be endurable in the patients with normal cardiovascular condition but is potential harmful to the patients with coronary heart disease. Thus it is critical to attenuate the cardiovascular stress induced by laryngoscopy and endotracheal intubation in the high risk patients.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: blood pressure(SBP)、diastolic blood pressure(DBP)、mean arterial pressure(MAP)
primary_outcome.time_frame: one second before anesthesia induction, the moment when tracheal catheter passes through glottis and at 1, 3, 5 min after tracheal intubation
primary_outcome.description: Under local anesthesia invasive artery line was put to the patients to monitor systolic blood pressure(SBP)、diastolic blood pressure(DBP)、mean arterial pressure(MAP)

intervention.description: induction with 0.3mg/kg of oxycodone in general anesthesia
induction with 0.3 µg/kg of Sufentanil in general anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
The coronary angiography from each patient showed that lesions exist in at least one main coronary artery
Exclusion Criteria:
a history of reactive airway disease, gastroesophageal reflux, morbid obesity, a known or predicted difficult airway

facility.name: shengjing hospital of China medical university
